newsitem.title: FRANCE: France asks US to hurry on peace move with EU.
newsitem.headline: France asks US to hurry on peace move with EU.

text.p: France urged the United States on Wednesday to take up quickly a European Union proposal for a joint peace initiative in the Middle East, saying fresh violence highlighted the urgent need for new peace moves.

"We strongly hope our American allies will respond to Europe's suggestion for joint action...Europe believes action must be taken very rapidly," Foreign Ministry spokesman Jacques Rummelhardt told a news briefing.

He said Paris was worried by fresh violence following the building of a new Israeli settlement in Arab east Jerusalem, and by mounting scepticism on the peace process in the two sides' public opinions.
"Taking the initiative to re-launch dialogue and the peace plan is more urgent than ever," Rummelhardt said.

Middle East department heads of the 15 EU member states, and the bloc's special envoy to the region, Miguel Angel Moratinos, agreed on Monday in Brussels to propose to President Bill Clinton a joint American-European initiative.

The proposal, including a "code of conduct" for Israelis and Palestinians, aims to take account of the need to ensure that past agreements are respected and to review all outstanding questions to re-launch negotiations.
The EU move came after Clinton and Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu apparently failed in Washington on Monday to overcome differences over Jewish settlements.
Netanyahu rebuffed all calls for a settlements freeze and said Israel would not surrender to "terrorism".
